 'Should' is an interesting word. Yes, in an ideal world men and women who engaged in unprotected sexual activity would then be responsible enough to deal with the consequences. Things don't always go as planned and, personally, I think that aborting a foetus before it can actually feel is a lot more humane then letting it mature into a child and then bringing that child into a world where they are not necessarily wanted.
 
 Neither are particularly nice scenarios for both the parents and the child. Therefore good sex education from a young age should be compulsory in order to warn people of the risks and then prepare them for eventual parenthood and the consequences, if they or their partner should fall pregnant.

While I am pro-life, I am also pro-sex ed. When kids start reaching pueberty, then what do they want to do? You guessed it! Have sex. But if they become promiscuous, then they'll want sex more and more and more. Condoms don't work 100% of the time, and there have been some reported cases that prove that a girl can get pregnant even when using condoms. If a sperm can get through, so can a virus. So promiscuity can not only lead to unwanted pregnancies, but also STDs. Comprehensive sex education is a very good way to get rid of this. This will lower abortion rates. I don't understand why so many people from both sides are against it, because it seems very logical.

When kids start reaching pueberty, then what do they want to do? You guessed it! Have sex.

 Bingo. And nothing anybody can do will stop this. For as long as there have been teenagers, there has been teenage sex. For as long as there are teenagers, there will be teenage sex. At least some people recognize this instead of trying to fight the impossible fight.
 
 
So promiscuity can not only lead to unwanted pregnancies, but also STDs.

 But not being promiscuous can also lead to these things. A girl who has had but a single partner can end up with an STD and a pregnancy. Promiscuity can be a problem, but it is not the problem many make it out to be. Use the condom properly, and your chance of avoiding both STDs and pregnancies is damn high. Contrary to the claims of despicable abstinence-only disinformation campaigns, viruses do not fit through pores of condoms. The problems arise from improper use or the rare breakage.
 
 
Comprehensive sex education is a very good way to get rid of this. This will lower abortion rates. I don't understand why so many people from both sides are against it, because it seems very logical.

Not to long ago, 150 to 200 years or so, it was common and accepted by society for teenagers to have sex and get married. That was the norm. Hell, back then, at 16, many were running companies and married with children. 
 
 But, since the Industrial Revolution, society said that you should finish your education, so you have to postpone sex and marriage until you are 18 and finish high school. But, the sexual desire is still there, just as it always was.
 
 Then, society says you have to go to college. Now this pushes sex and marriage back another couple of years, but the desire is still there.
 
 Now, we need to ever further our education, and push sex and marriage back a couple more years. But, the desire to have sex is still there. Think about that. 
 
 Teenagers mature as fast as society allows them. But, we all know they desire sex. That is why comprehensive sex ed is very, very important.
 
 And we all know why religious fundamentalists don't want to teach kids about sex. They can say whatever they want, but it's because they don't think people should have sex until they're married, which is absurd.

For one, The National Marriage Project done at Rutgers is secular and recent
"Also, a recent study based on a nationally-representative sample of women concluded that premarital cohabitation (and premarital sex), when limited to a woman’s future husband, is not associated with an elevated risk of marital disruption. What can be said for certain is that no evidence has yet been found that those who cohabit before marriage have stronger marriages than those who do not."
 http://marriage.rutgers.edu/Publications/SOOU/TEXTSOOU2006.htm
 
 "This article examines the relationship between premarital sexual activity and the long-term risk of divorce among U.S. women married between 1965 and 1985. Simple cross-tabulations from the 1988 National Survey of Family Growth indicate that women who were sexually active prior to marriage faced a considerably higher risk of marital disruption than women were were virgin brides. A bivariate probit model is employed to examine three possible explanations for this positive relationship: (a) a direct causal effect, (b) an indirect effect through intervening "high risk" behaviors (such as having a premarital birth or marrying at a young age), and (c) a selectivity effect representing prior differences between virgins and nonvirgins (such as family background or attitudes and values). After a variety of observable characteristics are controlled, nonvirgins still face a much higher risk of divorce than virgins. However, when the analysis controls for unobserved characteristics affecting both the likelihood of having premarital sex and the likelihood of divorce, the differential is no longer statistically significant. These results suggest that the positive relationship between premarital sex and the risk of divorce can be attributed to prior unobserved differences (e.g., the willingness to break traditional norms) rather than to a direct causal effect."
 http://www.jstor.org/pss/352992
